Hi JB, good to have some debate! I think we essentially agree...the fundam=
ental thing should be the "whether I learned something" criterion. And I wo=
uld qualify that as "whether I learned something *general*", i.e., that I t=
hink that will apply to other systems.

A quantitative comparison is often =
a good way to demonstrate something clearly. Then one can test significance=
, etc. However, one can also make quantitative comparisons that do not cont=
ribute to a clear take-away. For example, a common problem is papers that m=
easure something very specific to a particular system, while failing to giv=
e the reader any confidence that the conclusions can be generalized to othe=
r systems. Thus clearly it's possible to test a hypothesis, or make a quant=
itative comparison, that does not help the reader "learn something" from th=
e paper.

Yes I agree that in our field we should have the very highest sta=
ndards! I'm not saying that every paper that says "look, cool simulated rob=
ots" should be accepted. (And yes, I do feel your frustration with a histor=
ic glut of papers that show cool videos but don't try to provide any enduri=
ng take-away lesson.) I am saying that if a paper shows "unprecedented comp=
lexity" (subjectively defined) in the robot behavior, that is a real contri=
bution of the paper (and should push the reviewer toward acceptance - along=
 with good clear writing, reproducibility, etc. etc.)

In the GDS track we'=
re pursuing something called "complexity" which we don't yet agree how how =
to measure. When we do have good measures of complexity in the future, then=
 we will move into a more quantitatively demanding era of our field. But in=
 the meantime if something does appear to be subjectively "more complex" th=
an what has been published before, I don't think we should penalize the aut=
hor for not being able to measure it. It is currently a shortcoming of the =
whole field.

(Definitely a primary goal of the track should be to come up =
with suitable measures of complexity! We are not yet articulating this well=
 enough in the call for papers.)

So in the GDS track in particular, we are=
 in this special (short-lived, I hope!) period where we don't yet know how =
to measure the main thing we are after! But generally, in any scientific fi=
eld, that may be the case from time to time, especially in new fields. Vict=
orian naturalists spent a lot of time observing and describing nature; late=
r generations started to quantify evolution with population genetics. That'=
s OK.

Again, yes we agree, the fundamental criterion should be how importa=
nt and general are the lessons we learn from a paper. I am glad to hash thr=
ough these issues!

Cheers,

Mike
